quote: Before we get too carried away with this thread could you all please consider how the sd function calculates its result? [...] I'll tell you, it takes the square root of the variance. First you calculate the mean *using floating point arithmetic* in which it is not necessarily true that N * k / N == k [...] Most of those tests [for numerical accuracy] end in a check using the all.equal function which checks if the relative difference is less than a threshold. That's about the best that you can do with floating point arithmetic.<x>Here endeth the sermon.

quote: I'm really curious to know why the "two types" of sum of squares are called "Type I" and "Type III"! This is a very common misconception, particularly among SAS users who have been fed this nonsense quite often for all their professional lives. Fortunately the reality is much simpler. There is, by any sensible reckoning, only ONE type of sum of squares, and it always represents an improvement sum of squares of the outer (or alternative) model over the inner (or null hypothesis) model. What the SAS highly dubious classification of sums of squares does is to encourage users to concentrate on the null hypothesis model and to forget about the alternative. This is always a very bad idea and not surprisingly it can lead to nonsensical tests, as in the test it provides for main effects "even in the presence of interactions", something which beggars definition, let alone belief.
author: Bill Venables

quote: I was profoundly disappointed when I saw that S-PLUS 4.5 now provides "Type III" sums of squares as a routine option for the summary method for aov objects. I note that it is not yet available for multistratum models, although this has all the hallmarks of an oversight (that is, a bug) rather than common sense seeing the light of day. When the decision was being taken of whether to include this feature, "because the FDA requires it" a few of my colleagues and I were consulted and our reply was unhesitatingly a clear and unequivocal "No", but it seems the FDA and SAS speak louder and we were clearly outvoted.
author: Bill Venables

quote: I think we can reject the null hypothesis of "Dirk can type" at all convential significance levels.
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel
context: after several users including himself had misspelled Ubuntu as Umbutu or Ubunto

quote: The problem, as always, is what the heck does one mean by 'outlier' in these contexts. Seems to be like pornography -- "I know it when I see it."
author: Berton Gunter
context: quoting Justice Potter Stewart in a discussion about tests for outliers

quote: [...] (damn... my shift key just broke as well...)<x>bill venables.
author: Bill Venables
context: answering a message that lacked upper case letters

quote: It is a mistake to assume that everything is known about even the common approximations used in statistical practice, and this area is still opening up.
author: Bill Venables
context: in a discussion about how fitted generalized linear mixed models can be compared

quote: We are teaching stuff like mathematics, statistics, statistical programming and so on, but we cannot teach each possible software product - we also don't teach how to analyze each possible dataset that might find its way to the statistician's desk, we just use the iris data and Anscombe's quartet. ;-)
author: Uwe Ligges
context: in a thread about whether universities have to teach students how to use commercial software

quote: Usually (but not always) doing tests of normality reflect a lack of understanding of the power of rank tests, and an assumption of high power for the tests (qq plots don't always help with that because of their subjectivity). When possible it's good to choose a robust method. Also, doing pre-testing for normality can affect the type I error of the overall analysis.
author: Frank Harrell

quote: As for elegance, R is refined, tasteful, and beautiful. When I grow up, I want to marry R.
author: Andy Bunn
context: in a discussion about whether R is simple, powerful and elegant

quote: Frank Harrell: Here is an easy approach that will yield results only slightly less valid than one actually using the response variable:<x>  x <- data.frame(x1, x2, x3, x4, ..., other potential predictors)<x>  x[ , sample(ncol(x))]<x>Andy Liaw: Hmm... Shouldn't that be something like:<x>  x[, sample(ncol(x), ceiling(ncol(x) * runif(1)))]
author: Frank Harrell and Andy Liaw
context: about alternative strategies for stepwise regression and 'random parsimony'

quote: Rene M. Raupp: Does anybody know any work comparing R with other (charged) statistical software (like Minitab, SPSS, SAS)? [...] I have to show it's as good as the others.<x>Kjetil Brinchmann Halvorsen: Sorry. That will be difficult. Couldn't it do to prove it is better?
author: Rene M. Raupp and Kjetil Brinchmann Halvorsen

quote: Sean Davis: It got me going quickly with S4 methods, which it seems to me are the way to go in most cases.<x>Rolf Turner: If you want to simultaneously handcuff yourself, strap yourself into a strait jacket, and tie yourself in knots, and moreover write code which is incomprehensible to the human mind, then S4 methods are indeed the way to go.
author: Sean Davis and Rolf Turner
context: expressing different views about the benefits of S4 classes

quote: I wish to perform brain surgery this afternoon at 4pm and don't know where to start. My background is the history of great statistician sports legends but I am willing to learn. I know there are courses and numerous books on brain surgery but I don't have the time for those. Please direct me to the appropriate HowTos, and be on standby for solving any problem I may encounter while in the operating room. Some of you might ask for specifics of the case, but that would require my following the posting guide and spending even more time than I am already taking to write this note.
author: I. Ben Fooled
context: aka Frank Harrell

quote: You're overlooking something like line 800 of the documentation for xyplot. [...] It's probably in the R-FAQ as well, since my original feeling was that this behaviour was chosen in order to confuse people and see how many people read the FAQ... :)
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: about the fact that lattice objects have to be print()ed

quote: Rolf Turner: In the middle of a Saturday morning (in my Time Zone!) I send out a plea for help, and in just over 20 minutes my problem is solved!<x>I don't think you get service like that anywhere else. This R-help list is BLOODY AMAZING!<x>Spencer Graves: 'The sun never sets on the (former) British Empire.' Today, it never sets on R-Help.
author: Rolf Turner and Spencer Graves

quote: As a general rule (subject to numerous exceptions, caveats, etc.):<x>1) it is programming and debugging time that most impacts 'overall' program execution time;<x>2) this is most strongly impacted by code readability and size (the smaller the better);<x>3) both of which are enhanced by modular construction and reuseability, which argues for avoiding inline code and using separate functions.<x>These days, I would argue that most of the time it is program clarity and correctness (they are related) that is the important issue, not execution speed.
author: Berton Gunter
context: in a discussion about parsing speed

quote: I suggest that we redefine "+" to be a legal character in the name of an identifier. Sure, if you used to have "a+b" you'll have to rewrite it as "+(a,b)", but think of the benefits! You+can+write+out+long+sentences+and+use+them+as+variable+names!
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: in a discussion whether to use underscore, dot, or mixed case in variable names

quote: Oops. Was that what I was expecting?
author: Louise Matthews
context: during the practicals of 'Statistical Practice in Epidemiology Using R'

quote: Well, 'do as we say, not do as we do' applies, I think.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: answering a report on a small inconsistency in 'Writing R Extensions' by David Firth

quote: See pages 45 and 46 of V&R's S PROGRAMMING for a definitive discussion of how to do this.<x>(Confession: I treat anything that V&R say as definitive).
author: Berton Gunter
context: in reply to the question how to parse a '...' function argument

quote: A big computer, a complex algorithm and a long time does not equal science.
author: Robert Gentleman

quote: Uwe Ligges: I just told nonsense, stepclass() does not make sense with randomForest(), obviously ... (wonder why nobody shouted?).<x>Douglas Bates: Oh, we're just so used to you talking nonsense that we don't bother to point it out any more :-)
author: Uwe Ligges and Douglas Bates

quote: The fact that some people murder doesn't mean we should copy them. And murdering data, though not as serious, should also be avoided.
author: Frank E. Harrell
context: answering a question on categorization of continuous variables in survival modelling

quote: The learning curve is steep - but then like many people, I'd like to be able to do sophisticated modelling with deep understanding and no effort :-)
author: Sean O'Riordain
context: in a thread about the helpfulness of documentation

quote: Excellent, Berwin!<x>Specifically the part about why the bug never really triggers wrong behavior. Your mail should be saved in 'The Annals of R' ...
author: Martin Maechler
context: after Berwin A Turlach reported a buglet in 'spline_eval'

quote: You say yourself it wasn't reproducible. So it could have been anything that "crashed" your R, cosmic radiation, a bolt of lightning reversing a bit in your computer memory, ... :-)
author: Martin Maechler
context: replying to a bug report

quote: It was simple, but you know, it's always simple when you've done it.
author: Simone Gabbriellini
context: after solving a problem with a trick suggested on the list

quote: Trevor Hastie: It would be great to have a 'clickable' digest, where the topics list is a set of pointers, and clicking on a topic takes you to that entry.<x>Jeff Gentry: I sincerely hope you don't mean that you wish HTML enabled content in the actual emails coming through the mailing list. People who send HTML in email text should be taken out back and shot :)<x>Peter Dalgaard: Pretty much what my spam filter does... Well, it kills the message, not the sender, although the latter would be a more permanent solution.
author: Trevor Hastie, Jeff Gentry, and Peter Dalgaard

quote: If you aren't sure of the relative priority of two operators, use parentheses. 1:(nr-1) would work regardless of whether : or - had higher priority. Or, in extreme cases, read the documentation.
author: Duncan Murdoch

quote: It is wrong to blame ANY tool for our own shortcomings!
author: Robert Baer
context: about the perils of using PowerPoint

quote: Jason Horn: Can anyone think of a way to create a pretty() sequence that excludes zero? Or a way to remove the zero from a sequence after using pretty()?<x>Peter Dalgaard: The former is rather hard because zero is generally considered just about the prettiest number around...
author: Jason Horn and Peter Dalgaard

quote: Does anyone know someone working in this area in France who is not a JARP (Just Another R Person)?
author: Jan de Leeuw

quote: Contrary to popular belief the speed of R's interpreter is rarely the limiting factor to R's speed. People treating R like C is typically the limiting factor. You have vector operations, USE THEM.
author: Byron Ellis

quote: Mathematical conventions are just that, conventions. They differ by field of mathematics. Don't ask us why matrix rows are numbered down but graphs are numbered up the y axis, nor why x comes before y but row before column. But the matrix layout has always seemed illogical to me.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: answering a question why print(x) and image(x) are layouted differently

quote: Byron Ellis: If we wanted to be truly radical we'd just accept that graphics devices and event loops are just special cases of the connection and merge the whole thing, thus more-or-less reinventing CLIM. :-)<x>Anthony Rossini: Eventually, all programming languages grow up and become Lisp. (progress, progress, and more joyful progress on CLS).<x>Byron Ellis: Untrue! They may also become Smalltalk :-)
author: Byron Ellis and Anthony Rossini

quote: And the fear of getting Ripleyed on the mailing list also makes me think, read, and improve before submitting half baked questions to the list.
author: Eric Kort

quote: Ole F. Christensen: Brain, Thank you very much for your help.<x>Peter Dalgaard: You seem to be using call-by-value semantics rather than call-by-name...
author: Ole F. Christensen and Peter Dalgaard
context: thanking *Brian* D. Ripley for help

quote: Thomas Lumley: The precedence of ^ is higher than that of unary minus. It may be surprising, [...]<x>Herve Pages: No, it's not surprising. At least to me... In the country where I grew up, I've been teached that -x^2 means -(x^2) not (-x)^2.
author: Thomas Lumley and Herve Pages
context: both explaining that operator precedence is working perfectly well

quote: The wiki spamming is a serious problem, [...]. What does a logfile with IPs help? The spammers are strangers selling viagra. I don't want to find them :-)
author: Detlef Steuer
context: in a discussion on R wikis

quote: Any doubts about R's big-league status should be put to rest, now that we have a Sudoku Puzzle Solver. Take that, SAS!
author: David Brahm
context: announcing the sudoku package

quote: This list is impressive. People are knowledgable, opinionated, ready to help and to flame you for asking elementary question or asking how to use type III SSQ. So, speak softly and carry a beagle. Seriously, sometimes it would be quicker just to give an answer, than to flame a poor soul.
author: Milos Zarkovic

quote: Lastly, by what we could call the 'Liaw-Baron principle', every question that can be asked has in fact already been asked.
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel
context: citing Andy Liaw's and Jonathan Baron's opinion on unique questions on R-help

quote: It's not a question of trying variations, rather of following instructions.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: about using 'Writing R Extensions'

quote: Michael Dewey: When I started I found the free documents useful but I made most progress when I bought MASS. I do realise that liking books is a bit last millennium.<x>Thomas Lumley: Very late last millenium, though. "When I were young[er] we didn't have all these fancy yellow books."
author: Michael Dewey and Thomas Lumley
context: about different kinds of documentation for R

quote: Please do think hard before you tell other people what they 'should' do for you.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: It might surprise many R-help posters, but R has manuals as well...
author: Uwe Ligges

quote: Tom Backer Johnsen: I have just started looking at R, and are getting more and more irritated at myself for not having done that before. However, one of the things I have not found in the documentation is some way of preparing output from R for convenient formatting into something like MS Word.<x>Barry Rowlingson: Well whatever you do, don't start looking at LaTeX, because that will get you even more irritated at yourself for not having done it before.
author: Tom Backer Johnsen and Barry Rowlingson

quote: Michael Watson: Hopefully this one isn't in the manual or I am about to get shot :-S<x>Peter Dalgaard: *Kapow*...
author: Michael Watson and Peter Dalgaard
context: question on axis()

quote: My solution when I run into mysteries like this is to put 'browser()' in the function just before or after the line of interest. The magnitude and direction of my stupidity usually become clear quickly.
author: Patrick Burns

quote: Similarly to Brian, I'm much more reluctant to help people who don't exist -- who knows, maybe you're a computer program who has just passed the Turing test :-)
author: Martin Maechler
context: about postings with anonymous e-mail addresses and without real names

quote: There's probably some examples, but there are some examples of people using<x>  solve(t(X) %*% W %*% X) %*% W %*% Y<x>to compute regression coefficients, too.
author: Thomas Lumley
context: discussing usefulness of evaluation order in lapply

quote: (3 times...rrrrgh...) and why do you think the mailing list is called R-*packages* ???????????<x>Please do<x>  for(i in 1:20) cat("It's a package!\n")
author: Martin Maechler
context: after a newly released *package* has been called *library* three times in its announcement on R-packages

quote: If we do that, I predict that the total amount of r-help time wasted on it will exceed the CPU time saved by orders of magnitude.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: after a specialized function speeding up detection of NAs was suggested for base R

quote: This has been discussed before in this list, and Ripley said "no, no!". I do it all the time, but only in secrecy.
author: Jari Oksanen
context: about replacing zero distances with tiny values for isoMDS()

quote: 2-D pie charts are terrible. That makes 3-D pie charts terrible to the 3/2 power.
author: Frank Harrell

quote: Yourexamplesmightactuallybereadableifyouusedyourspacebar.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: answering a question containing code without any spaces

quote: It seems that you are facing a very serious fortune(122) problem.
author: Jean R. Lobry
context: in reply to a user that quickly needed help for his PhD thesis, without properly checking the documentation

quote: Duncan Murdoch: Others need to run under ESS.<x>Francois Pinard: While this is a good things for Emacs lovers, the requirement is rather unwelcome for pagans! :-)
author: Duncan Murdoch and Francois Pinard
context: on the availability of command completion

quote: When talking about user friendliness of computer software I like the analogy of cars vs. busses: [...]<x>Using this analogy programs like SPSS are busses, easy to use for the standard things, but very frustrating if you want to do something that is not already preprogrammed.<x>R is a 4-wheel drive SUV (though environmentally friendly) with a bike on the back, a kayak on top, good walking and running shoes in the passenger seat, and mountain climbing and spelunking gear in the back. R can take you anywhere you want to go if you take time to learn how to use the equipment, but that is going to take longer than learning where the bus stops are in SPSS.
author: Greg Snow

quote: Oh, gosh, this is getting whimsical.<x>R, I surmise, is a mutable tool that enables the user to do what they want. Knapped flint for the Stone Age statistical fool, plasma arc for the expert and learned savant.<x>R is a friend to all manner of men. The perfect companion, the servant complete. It gently informeth the clueless and then, reveals the essence unto the esthete.
author: Jim Lemon
context: in a discussion about the usability of R

quote: Statistical computing is not easy, so how could R be? Who has ever claimed it is? Any package that makes statistical computing appear to be easy is probably giving you wrong answers half the time, or is extremely limited in scope.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: in a discussion about the usability of R

quote: Jarek Tuszynski: At one company [...] I had to run all the licenses of all the software [...] through the legal department. When they read the GNU Public License (GPL) their only comment was: We have no idea what that license means. Do not touch any software using it.<x>Rolf Turner: This is typical of lawyers' minds. If something is clear, rational, lucid, straightforward, unambigous, means what it says ... they can't understand it.
author: Jarek Tuszynski and Rolf Turner
context: in a discussion about the GPL and 'buying R'

quote: It is unusual for the actual data not to be available in real problems.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: in reply to a question how to fit a distribution if not the data but only their histogram is available

quote: Warning: Although abusing R was not proved to be addictive, it should be noted that it often leads to harder stuff.
author: Ivan Mizera (self-confessed abuseR)

quote: I wish <<- had never been invented, as it makes an esoteric and dangerous feature of the language *seem* normal and reasonable. If you want to dumb down R/S into a macro language, this is the operator for you.
author: Bill Venables

quote: John Kane: I have 120 columns in a data.frame. I have one value in a column named "blaw" that I want to change. How do I find the coordinates?<x>Roger Koenker: It is the well-known wicked which problem: If you had (grammatically incorrectly) thought "... which I want to change" then you might have been led to type (in another window):<x>  ?which<x>and you would have seen the light. Maybe that() should be an alias for which()?
author: John Kane and Roger Koenker

quote: Gregor Gorjanc: But imagine how hard would it be to have two separate modes ... argh, probably a mess^2 or have I missed something obvious.<x>Martin Maechler: Yes, exactly: "Mess ^ 2" -- and if you allow both 'drop' and 'na.rm' options, it's "Mess ^ 3" -- not something anyone really wants!
author: Gregor Gorjanc and Martin Maechler
context: in a discussion whether 'drop' should be set in options(), possibly depending on different user vs. programmer modes

quote: You need to prepare your students for the future, not the past.
author: Spencer Graves
context: making a case for using R in academia

quote: Have you ever wanted to write a book, but not known where to start? Now is a very good time to jump in, because there is currently a very simple recipe for success: just put R in the title and you will have to beat the publishers off with a stick!
author: Paul Murrell

quote: This is at best a matter of opinion, and credentials do matter for opinions.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: in response to the claim that only 1.79e3 is printed with three significant digits whereas 1790 is not

quote: If you want to do an integer divide, you should only use integers to divide with.
author: Thierry Onkelinx
context: (not entirely correctly) in an answer to "understanding integer divide (%/%)"

quote: Personally I have never regretted trying not to underestimate my own future stupidity.
author: Greg Snow
context: explaining why eval(parse(...)) is often suboptimal, answering a question triggered by the infamous fortune(106)

quote: Brian Ripley: Where did you tell it [...]? (Nowhere: R is lacking a mind_read() function!)<x>Peter Dalgaard: Please stop complaining about missing features. Patches will be considered.<x><x>Oh, it's you, Brian. Never mind then. You'll get to it, I'm sure. ;-)
author: Brian Ripley and Peter Dalgaard
context: answering why abline(lm(x~y)) would not work

quote: Just [use] MinGW like R [does], following the guides to the letter gets you there like marked stones across a marsh. Leaving the path usually gets you at best neck deep in the mire, alternatively just bubbles.
author: Roger Bivand
context: explaining what development environment should be used to develop C on Windows (for R)

quote: You must realize that R is written by experts in statistics and statistical computing who, despite popular opinion, do not believe that everything in SAS and SPSS is worth copying. Some things done in such packages, which trace their roots back to the days of punched cards and magnetic tape when fitting a single linear model may take several days because your first 5 attempts failed due to syntax errors in the JCL or the SAS code, still reflect the approach of "give me every possible statistic that could be calculated from this model, whether or not it makes sense". The approach taken in R is different. The underlying assumption is that the useR is thinking about the analysis while doing it.
author: Douglas Bates
context: in reply to the suggestion to include type III sums of squares and lsmeans in base R to make it more similar to SAS or SPSS

quote: I don't like to see the use of c() for its side effects. In this case Marc's as.vector seems to me to be self-explanatory, and that is a virtue in programming that is too often undervalued.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: on how to convert a matrix into a vector

quote: I cannot remember if I have been using 14 or 14, I think it was 14 and I am not near the machine to check.
author: John Kane
context: confused about his SPSS version

quote: Tony Plate: There looks to be a typo in the R-exts manual: [...]<x>Peter Dalgaard: 'svn blame' tells me that this was Brian's addition in rev.35362 [...]<x>Brian D. Ripley: I prefer 'svn praise' myself.<x>Peter Dalgaard: Or 'svn annotate'. I think it depends on what I'm looking for, plus the risk that the author (perpetrator, contributor) might be me...
author: Tony Plate, Peter Dalgaard, and Brian D. Ripley
context: about a typo in the documentation

quote: Corinna Schmitt: How can I divide the number 0.285 with 2. I need a function.<x>  Result: 0.285 / 2 = 0.1425<x>Gabor Csardi: Well, i think<x>  half.of.0.285 <- function() {<x>    0.1425<x>  }<x>would do the trick.
author: Corinna Schmitt and Gabor Csardi

quote: Perhaps one is the real forge and the other is a forgery? Or a forge-R-y? I'll get my coat...
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: on the question whether http://www.RForge.net/ or http://R-Forge.R-project.org/ is the official forge server

quote: It is all too easy for statistical thinking to be swamped by programming tasks.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: R is being used for different purposes than the original interactive EDA environment.
author: Duncan Temple Lang

quote: RAM is cheap and thinking hurts.
author: Uwe Ligges
context: about memory requirements in R

quote: All this becomes even more glaring if you take the unusal step of plotting the data.
author: Bill Venables
context: interpreting the results of an ANOVA analysis

quote: What sort of editor would overlook this clear and demonstrable message leaping out from the data in favour of some arcane argument about "types of sums of squares"? Several answers come to mind: A power freak, a SAS afficianado, an idiot.
author: Bill Venables

quote: If you really want to assess uncertainty you need to take into account that the models are false and that several models may capture different aspects of the data and so be false in different ways.
author: Brian D. Ripley

quote: R will always be arcane to those who do not make a serious effort to learn it. It is **not** meant to be intuitive and easy for casual users to just plunge into. It is far too complex and powerful for that. But the rewards are great for serious data analysts who put in the effort.
author: Berton Gunter

quote: If anything, there should be a Law: Thou Shalt Not Even Think Of Producing A Graph That Looks Like Anything From A Spreadsheet.
author: Ted Harding
context: in a discussion about producing graphics

quote: Friends don't let friends use Excel for statistics!
author: Jonathan D. Cryer
context: about problems with using Microsoft Excel for statistics

quote: Anand Patil: Can this be fixed without requiring the user to do anything?<x>Brian D. Ripley: The fix requires 'the user' to read the documentation.
author: Anand Patil and Brian D. Ripley
context: about some compiler problems under Windows Vista

quote: Bad English is the language of science.
author: Jan de Leeuw

quote: 3-D bar plots are an abomination. Just because Excel can do them doesn't mean you should.<x>(Dismount pulpit).
author: Berton Gunter

quote: Actually the documentation of sunflowerplot is wrong in botanical sense. Sunflowers have composite flowers in capitula, and the things called 'petals' in documentation are ligulate, sterile ray-florets (each with vestigial petals which are not easily visible in sunflower, but in some other species you may see three (occasionally two) teeth).
author: Jari Oksanen

quote: Apparently mathematical impossibility is not an impediment to parameter estimation in such cases.
author: Douglas Bates
context: about the abilities of SAS PROC MIXED

quote: memory problems (not me. my pc!)
author: Sara Mouro
context: subject line for an R-help request

quote: Gustaf Rydevik: The author also has some thought-provoking opinions on R being no-good and that you should write everything in C.<x>Paul Gilbert: People used to say assembler, that's progress.
author: Gustaf Rydevik and Paul Gilbert
context: in a discussion about an 'R is slow' blog post

quote: Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.<x>Leo Tolstoy<x><x>and every messy data is messy in its own way - it's easy to define the characteristics of a clean dataset (rows are observations, columns are variables, columns contain values of consistent types). If you start to look at real life data you'll see every way you can imagine data being messy (and many that you can't)!
author: Hadley Wickham
context: answering 'in what way messy data sets are messy'

quote: I strongly suggest you collaborate with a local statistician. I can think of no circumstance where multiple regression on "hundreds of thousands of variables" is anything more than a fancy random number generator.
author: Berton Gunter

quote: The "right" place to store information like this in Windows is in the registry, but we've been reluctant to use it, for various historical reasons. In fact, we were just told today that editing the registry is not allowed by software used by the US government. I think they'll be moving back to the abacus, if they want to stay with Windows.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: about where to store some Windows GUI preferences

quote: I recently read the small print on the academic license our site has for SAS. You have to:<x><x>  1 inform SAS of any taught courses that use SAS,<x>  2 inform SAS of any research projects using SAS,<x>  3 allow SAS to refer to your institution as a SAS user,<x>  4 allow SAS to review your taught courses,<x>  5 ensure your courses are taught using qualified personnel,<x>  6 give SAS your first-born male offspring.<x><x>I spoke to our site's licensing supremos and they say they've never heard of anyone complying with 1 or 2. Point 4 sounds like petty fiddling in our educational business, and point 5 left 'qualified' undefined. Point 6 doesn't bother me since I don't have kids.
author: Barry Rowlingson

quote: The "one size fits all" approach to data analysis - also known as "give me a quart and a half of statistics and just make sure that there is a p-value less than 5% somewhere in there" - doesn't fit well into the R system.
author: Douglas Bates

quote: In many cases a) often looks difficult, but on closer inspection turns out to be impossible.
author: Bill Venables
context: about calculating the negative log-likelihood from a non-independence model

quote: Basically R is reluctant to let you shoot yourself in the foot unless you are really determined to do so.
author: Bill Venables
context: about the warning hist() issues when being called with unequal interval widths and freq=TRUE

quote: Whoops! I read that e+24 as e-24, so scrub all that I said.<x>(You'd think, that having seen Bill Venables make a similar error -- which he corrected in the follow-up posting to which I was replying -- I would've been more careful. Well, you'd think wrong. Actually it *was* e-24 when I posted; then the Gremlins got in and changed everything. :-) )
author: Rolf Turner
context: discussing that f.root from uniroot() is (not) almost zero

quote: R may be the wrong tool for the job, but it's the wrong job.
author: Rolf Turner
context: about solving 100th degree polynomials

quote: Kenn Konstabel: [...] There's more to this trend: SPSS and Statistica now advertise "R language support": [...]<x>Charles C. Berry: If you can't beat R, join R.<x>Marc Schwartz: "Resistance is futile. You will be assimilated."
author: Kenn Konstabel, Charles C. Berry, and Marc Schwartz
context: about the RPro release from REvolution

quote: As for the question of the bug in `is', ... it depends what your definition of `is' is.
author: Douglas Bates
context: referring to Bill Clinton after a tortuous discussion of the behavior of is(7, "integer")

quote: Shan-Ho Chou: I got a question about eigenvector. I've tried input a symmetric matrix to both R (using eigen function) and Minitab, but the result is really different. Can anyone tell me what's wrong with that?<x>Bill Venables: Simple. Minitab must be broken. Have you reported it to them?
author: Shan-Ho Chou and Bill Venables

quote: I still don't know what to do about the compromise between how statistics should be done and how journal editors seem to insist it should be done ...
author: Ben Bolker

quote: Nothing exceeds like Excel.
author: Roger Koenker
context: in reply to a question why it takes so long to paste 19,000 lines of R code from Excel into R

quote: Fabio Mulazzani: I need to obtain all the 9.somethingExp157 permutations that can be given from the numbers from 1 to 100.<x>Ted Harding: To an adequate approximation there are 10^158 of them. Simply to obtain them all (at a rate of 10^10 per second, which is faster than the CPU frequency of most desktop computers) would take 10^148 seconds, or slightly longer than 3*(10^140) years. Current estimates of the age of the Universe are of the order of 1.5*(10^10) years, so the Universe will have to last about 2*(10^130) times as long as it has already existed, before the task could be finished. So: why do you want to do this?
author: Fabio Mulazzani and Ted Harding

quote: Cross posting is sociopathic.
author: Roger Koenker

quote: Some people familiar with R describe it as a supercharged version of Microsoft's Excel spreadsheet software.
author: Ashlee Vance
context: in his article "Data Analysts Captivated by R's Power"

quote: I think [R] addresses a niche market for high-end data analysts that want free, readily available code. [...] We have customers who build engines for aircraft. I am happy they are not using freeware when I get on a jet.
author: Anne H. Milley
context: director of technology product marketing at SAS, quoted in Ashlee Vance's article "Data Analysts Captivated by R's Power"

quote: It's interesting that SAS Institute feels that non-peer-reviewed software with hidden implementations of analytic methods that cannot be reproduced by others should be trusted when building aircraft engines.
author: Frank Harrell
context: in response to the statement of the SAS director of technology product marketing: "We have customers who build engines for aircraft. I am happy they are not using freeware when I get on a jet."

quote: This sounds like you have discovered homeopathic properties in Sweave! It will be serious if input files remember errors even after they have been removed.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: after a user reported that two supposedly identical Rnw documents work and lead to an error, respectively

quote: Many problems come as a result of users forgetting that they are smarter than the computer. I see 3 ways to remedy the problem:<x>1. Make computers that are as smart or smarter than people.<x>2. Make the programmers anticipate every way that someone may use a particular function and make them implement all of the functionality even if they don't think it is worth the time/effort since there is an easy work around for many of the less likely used features.<x>3. Don't expect the computer to guess correctly and tell it exactly what you want it to do.
author: Greg Snow
context: in response to the question why as.Date() would not parse "13/1/2001" in 'the only reasonable way'

quote: One of the beauties of S and R is the syntax closeness to mathematical notation. Many of us know that Lisp has beauties that S can never have, but that's really in different beauty-space.
author: Martin Maechler

quote: R is Open Source and so you can modify it to emulate the bugs in other software: that is not one of the aims of its developers so please don't expect us to do so for you.
author: Brian D. Ripley
context: answering a request for a change to Excel-like non IEC 60559 standard conform rounding

quote: The combination of some data and an aching desire for an answer does not ensure that a reasonable answer can be extracted from a given body of data.
author: John W. Tukey
context: the first of six "basics" against statistician's hubrises

quote: I must say I feel very uneasy about giving advice on how to use R as a pre-processor for something that is to be done in Excel, but we are a broad church here!
author: Bill Venables

quote: No matter how much progress is made by the developers of screen readers somehow PDF remains less than accessible. It's a bit like a failed relationship in which one partner tries to win the other back with expensive gifts.
author: Paul R. Stanley
context: in a discussion about text-to-speech processors for the benefit of blind users of LaTeX

quote: As the name says, studentizing is left as an easy student exercise. Destudentizing is more difficult and usually called professorizing.
author: Dieter Menne
context: in response to a question whether residuals from nls() are studentized

quote: Hmm. I don't ever use R-squared, so I didn't implement it.
author: Thomas Lumley
context: in reply to a question about how to compute R-squared using biglm

quote: The issue really comes down to the fact that the questions: "exactly normal?", and "normal enough?" are 2 very different questions (with the difference becoming greater with increased sample size) and while the first is the easier to answer, the second is generally the more useful one.
author: Greg Snow
context: answering a question about a "normality test" suitable for large data

quote: Trellis graphics are a bit like hash functions: you can be close to the target, but get a far-off result.
author: Dieter Menne
context: about problems with creating a suitable lattice panel function

quote: The only people who should use the assign function are those who fully understand why you should never use the assign function.
author: Greg Snow

quote: 4 bits are not enough for me!
author: Philippe Grosjean
context: after conference dinner incl. wine in a conversation about the representation of data in the ff package

quote: Kelvin Lam: My institute has been heavily dependent on SAS for the past while, and SAS is starting to charge us a very deep amount for license renewal. Since we are a non-profit organization that is definitely not sustainable. The team is brainstorming possibility of switching to R, at least gradually. I am talking about the entire institute with considerable number of analysts using SAS their entire career. There's a handful of us using R regularly. What kind of problems and challenges have you faced?<x>Frank Harrell: One of your challenges will be that with the increased productivity of the team you will have time for more intellectually challenging problems. That frustrates some people.
author: Kelvin Lam and Frank Harrell

quote: Yes we CRAN!
author: Aurelien Latouche
context: suggestion for a T-shirt slogan

quote: Dear Uwe, thank you very much for your unvaluable time and effort.
author: Javier Cano
context: thanking Uwe Ligges for solving a coding problem

quote: If I were to be treated by a cure created by stepwise regression, I would prefer voodoo.
author: Dieter Menne
context: in a thread about regressions with many variables

quote: If one doesn't understand the output of lm(), then one's knowledge of statistics is insufficient to warrant using lm().
author: Peter Ehlers

quote: If 'fools rush in where angels fear to tread', then Bayesians 'jump' in where frequentists fear to 'step'.
author: Charles C. Berry
context: about Bayesian model selection as an alternative to stepwise regression

quote: You are going to need a few more sessions for this therapy to be useful, we cannot read your computer's mind, just interpret what you tell us. I don't want to jump ahead, but can you tell us the childhood of your crashes, etc.
author: Romain Francois
context: in a 'psychotherapy' session trying to understand the sources of a useR's problems

quote: It currently works (because I can't figure out how to make it an error) but you really should not do it.
author: Hadley Wickham
context: discussing a user's ggplot experiences

quote: There's an informal tradition that those announcements [about R releases] contain at least one mistake, but apparently I forgot this time, so users have to make up their own....
author: Peter Dalgaard
context: about an apparent non-bug report in his former R-announce message

quote: It appears to me that you do not understand even basic statistics. As a corollary to that impression I would suggest that giving you advice about the use of R for scientific investigation could be morally similar to giving you advice about how to do your own household wiring.
author: David Winsemius

quote: Kakali Das: Is there any certification courses available in statistics in India which can be done after completing M.Sc. in Statistics? I need to know some courses which will be a specialization and can be done in distance mode from India?<x>Kjetil Brinchmann Halvorsen: A specialization course (maybe better named generalization course) suitable to everybody, very cheap, and of immense quality, is to participate in the mailing list R-help, and simply try to understand (and then respond usefully) to questions arising there.
author: Kakali Das and Kjetil Brinchmann Halvorsen

quote: In general, it's much easier to create output from a R object than create an R object from output.
author: Hadley Wickham

quote: As Obi-Wan Kenobi may have said in Star Wars: "Use the source, Luke!"
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: answering a question on the documentation of some implementation details

quote: Finally, a word of wisdom from a long-ago engineering colleague: "Whenever I see an outlier, I'm never sure whether to throw it away or patent it."
author: Berton Gunter
context: on outlier identification

quote: As one of the developers of the nls function I would like to state that the lack of automatic ANOVA, R^2 and adj. R^2 from nls is a feature, not a bug :-)
author: Douglas Bates
context: in reply to a request for automatic ANOVA of NLS models as in Statistica

quote: My best advice regarding R^2 statistics with nonlinear models is, as Nancy Reagan suggested, "Just say no.".
author: Douglas Bates

quote: I recently attended a Ph.D. prelim exam where the candidate had proposed research on various ways of defining an R^2 statistic in the original data scale from a linear model fit to data in a transformed scale determined by the Box-Cox method. There were seven different possible definitions for R^2, all of which, as acknowledged by the candidate and by the thesis advisor, were incorrect. The purpose of this path-breaking study is to determine in some way which of these seven possible incorrect definitions should be used. My suggestion that the obvious answer was "none of them" was regarded as somewhat heretical.
author: Douglas Bates

quote: [Listing original copyright holders in R packages is] especially useful if there are areas of doubt and uncertainty (eg code published on ftp sites before people worried about licenses), since it at least gives you rigidly defined areas of doubt and uncertainty.[5]<x>[5] Adams D, (1978) Hitchhiker's Guide. BBC Radio.
author: Thomas Lumley
context: in a discussion about copyright vs. licenses

quote: The widespread use of spreadsheets or SPSS data sets or SAS data sets which encourage the "single table with a gargantuan number of columns, most of which are missing data in most cases" approach to organization of longitudinal data is regrettable.
author: Douglas Bates
context: in a discussion about software for hierarchical data sets

quote: R is a complex program. If you can't work out how to find the documentation, I doubt you will be able to use R.
author: David Kirby
context: in response to a vague question on where to find documentation for R

quote: If your ultimate interest is in real scientific progress, I'd suggest that you ignore that sentence (and any conclusion drawn subsequent to it).
author: Andy Liaw
context: in response to a question on the meaning of the sentence: 'Independent variables whose correlation with the response variable was not significant at 5% level were removed'

quote: I begin to think that R needs a _mis_fortunes package...
author: Stephen L.R. Ellison

quote: I think what we are seeking is the marginal variance-covariance matrix of the parameter estimators (marginal with respect to the random effects random variable, B), which would have the form of the inverse of the crossproduct of a (q+p) by p matrix composed of the vertical concatenation of - L^{-1}RZX RX^{-1} and RX^{-1}. (Note: You do *not* want to calculate the first term by inverting L, use solve(L, RZX, system = "L") - [...] don't even think about using solve(L) - don't!, don't!, don't! - have I made myself clear? - don't do that (and we all know that someone will do exactly that for a very large L and then send out messages about "R is SOOOOO SLOOOOW!!!!" :-) )
author: Douglas Bates

quote: Only with a very high signal to noise ratio (e.g., high true R^2) can torturing data lead to a confession to something other than what the analyst wants to hear.
author: Frank Harrell

quote: If you don't want informative help files, it's really not much work to make uninformative ones.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: in response to a question how to install a package without editing .Rd files appropriately before

quote: Dave Lubbers: R 2.7.2 - the manual says configure, make, which is what I did. So I did read the manual and followed the directions. The manual is too terse to get me there.<x>Duncan Murdoch: You used the wrong tense. In referring to R 2.7.2, only past tenses are grammatically correct. If you want to say the manual *is* too terse, then you need to install R 2.11.0.
author: Dave Lubbers and Duncan Murdoch
context: on where to find libRmath

quote: Soham: How to compute the p-value of a statistic generally?<x>Berton Gunter: runif(1)
author: Soham and Berton Gunter

quote: Karl Ove Hufthammer: Why not use 'predict.loess' (i.e., 'predict' on a loess object) directly?<x>Greg Snow: Because that would be simple, straightforward, and make sense, and not require knowledge about less obvious functions.
author: Karl Ove Hufthammer and Greg Snow

quote: This reminds me of a quote I saw once (I think it may have been in one of those Murphy's Laws calendars), my parahpase:<x><x>If you make someone think that they are thinking,<x>      They will love you for it.<x>If you make them actually think,<x>      They will hate you for it.<x><x>This explains why people love pie charts and hate more effective graphs.
author: Greg Snow

quote: On average, any data manipulation that can be described in a sentence or two of English can be programmed in one line in R. If you find yourself writing a long 'for' loop to do something that sounds simple, take a step back and research if an existing combination of functions can easily handle your request.
author: Erik Iverson

quote: There are actual error messages, and until you show them, we can not help as the mind reading machine is currently off for repairs.
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel
context: after reports about errors with R CMD check

quote: Knut Krueger: Is there any function available to combine those p values?<x>Stephan Kolassa: ?"+"
author: Knut Krueger and Stephan Kolassa
context: about ways to combine p values from different tests

quote: So, with the item in the original query:<x><x>  if (x<-3) do_something;<x><x>if they wrote it as<x><x>  if (x<(-3)) do_something;<x><x>there would be no problem (and no doubt about what went with what). Of course in complicated expressions this could induce an episode of ocular lispopia, but apart from that it's safe!
author: Ted Harding
context: about potential confusion between assignment and comparisons with negative numbers

quote: Spencer Graves: What do you think about adding a "No RTFM" policy to the R mailing lists?<x>Michael Dewey: You raise an interesting point but the responses to your post remind us that people (and indeed whole cultures) are not all situated at the same point on the continuum of directness between "It's a cow, stupid" and "From this side it looks not unlike a cow".
author: Spencer Graves and Michael Dewey
context: reply after a long discussion of a potential "No RTFM" policy

quote: Dirk Eddelbuettel: Could it get any more un-scientific and un-empirical? Maybe we should debate whether it is faster on Thursdays than on Wednesdays too?<x>Thomas Lumley: That's easy. It's faster on Wednesdays, because faculty meeting and seminar are on Thursday (so more faculty are on campus using the computers) and homework for the applied regression sequence is due on Friday (so more students are using the computers).
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel and Thomas Lumley
context: after a rather vague disucssion which language is fastest for numerical computations

quote: datayoda: Bing is my friend...I found the cumsum() function.<x>Dirk Eddelbuettel: If bing is your friend, then rseek.org is bound to be your uncle.
author: datayoda and Dirk Eddelbuettel
context: after searching for a function that computes cumulative sums

quote: This is one of those cases, in my opinion, where R's documentation drops you into a flat landscape, in the middle of nowhere, in a thick mist.
author: Ted Harding
context: helping a user confused about R's partial matching behavior

quote: I used a heuristic... pulled from my posterior. That makes it Bayesian, right?
author: JD Long
context: in a not too serious chat about modeling strategies

quote: If you can do with[out a] Makefile, do without a Makefile.
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel
context: in a discussion about the benefits of (not) changing the compiler in R packages

quote: We also have huge amounts of work going into calibration transfer, i.e. making quantitative predictive models work on a different instrument. This is always a whole lot of work, and for some fields of problems at the moment considered basically impossible even between two instruments of the same model and manufacturer.
author: Claudia Beleits
context: in a discussion about publication bias and scientific validity

quote: This reminds me of a famous FORTRAN code snippet:<x><x>10 STOP<x>STOP<x>STOP<x>! IN CASE STILL SKIDDING<x>GOTO 10<x>
author: Carl Witthoft
context: in response to the question how to completely stop R scripts after stop()

quote: There is a reason that the speedometer in your car doesn't just read "slow" and "fast".
author: Frank Harrell
context: warning about the use of cutoffs after logistic regression

quote: The style for JSS now enforces (via Achimitization) the use of quotes.
author: Michael Friendly
context: on whether to quote or not to quote arguments like library("Hmisc") or help("mean")

quote: Although there is almost never a "No" in R, the best short answer is: "No".
author: Uwe Ligges
context: in response to the question whether R has a concept of "const objects" as in C++ that avoid modification

quote: Tested solutions offered when reproducible examples are provided.
author: David Winsemius
context: suggesting a potential solution to a vague problem description

quote: The good way to do it is to include the following comment at the beginning:<x># This is a holy Script, please edit it not
author: Kenn Konstabel
context: on "... how to protect R Script files from inadvertent editing by users."

quote: Sorry, but this is the R-help list.  The 'R Spam' list is over at /dev/null.
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel
context: after a poster misused the mailing list for advertising

quote: You might also consider a more informative subject line. "Help needed" is true for all questions (not answers) on R-help. Just think, why is this list called R-***help***?
author: Peter Ehlers
context: after answering a help request

quote: I think this is kind of like asking "will your Land Rover make it up my driveway?", but I'll assume the question was asked in all seriousness.
author: Ista Zahn
context: in response to a request for replication of some data preprocessing done in SAS

quote: In those first years after Bell Labs it was always a struggle to maintain my access to S and Port -- actually even Unix was a problem. I recall the director of campus computing services telling me that Unix wasn't appropriate for educational institutions since it was "too flexible."
author: Roger Koenker
context: in a discussion about nlminb

quote: Joshua Wiley: ... the advantages of formal classes seem worth at least not entirely dismissing.<x>Jim Lemon: Hmmm, yeah, that's about the grammatical equivalent of S4 classes.
author: Joshua Wiley and Jim Lemon
context: in a discussion about the relative advantages of S3 and S4 classes

quote: For recursive objects, search for recursive objects.
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: in a thread about "Recursive objects" and how to search for former discussions about the topic

quote: Most people pay infinitely more to Microsoft for Windows than they pay to R Core for R. I hope that's also the ratio of their complaints to Microsoft about this bug to their complaints to us about R.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: after a report that the default R version associated with .R files could not be changed in the standard Windows dialogs

quote: The trouble with nonstandard evaluation is that it doesn't follow standard evaluation rules...
author: Peter Dalgaard
context: about nonstandard evaluation in the curve() function

quote: Vaishali Sadaphal: I need to give my R code to my client to use. I would like to protect the logic/algorithms that have been coded in R. This means that I would not like anyone to be able to read the code.<x>Duncan Murdoch: R is an open source project, so providing ways for you to do this is not one of our goals. [...] If you think your client will steal from you, then you should find another client.
author: Vaishali Sadaphal and Duncan Murdoch

quote: Well..... SAS is SAS, but R is FREE...
author: Abhishek Rathore
context: in a discussion about R vs. SAS

quote: It is becoming apparent that you do not know how to use the results from either system. The progress of science would be safer if you get some advice from a person that knows what they are doing.
author: David Winsemius
context: in response to a user that obtained different linear regression results in R and SPSS and wanted to know which one to use

quote: For quite a while, bug-for-bug compatibility with S-PLUS v 3.x was considered important to allow people to port their packages between systems.
author: Peter Dalgaard

quote: I've been reading Data Analysis Using Regression and Multilevel/Hierarchical Models by Gelman and Hill. I'm getting acquainted with my new cartoon character friends Elmer (lmer) and Bugs, and at some point it may become clear what is going on. At the moment though, the whole thing seems a bit Looney Tunes.
author: Paul Miller

quote: Thank your for your entry in the Poorly Capitalized and Inadequately Searched Posting Contest. You will be advised of your ranking in due course.
author: David Winsemius
context: in response to an all-lower-case question on a simple clustering task

quote: Don't do as I say, do as Hadley does.
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: in a discussion about the workflow for writing R packages, see also fortune(128)

quote: R is wonderful, but it cannot work magic.
author: Rolf Turner
context: answering a request for automatic generation of 'data from a known mean and 95% CI'

quote: If we told you all of R's secrets, we'd have to kill you.
author: Duncan Murdoch
context: answering a request for too detailed documentation

quote: I know barely more than zero about R: until yesterday I didn't know how to spell it.
author: Pete Wilson

quote: Kevin Wright: Doug already mentioned the limitations of open source optimization code. Open source has benefits, but simply being open doesn't necessarily mean better.<x><x>Joshua Wiley: Actually, a series of studies I have conducted including theoretical proofs and empirical evidence proves open source to be unequivocally better. If you are interested, you can pay me to use the assertion, but the supporting details are restricted so you must accept that my internal checks and quality control are sufficient and the findings are correct and accurate. Details follow.<x><x>License and Use of I. Ben Fooled's findings:<x><x>"Open source is unequivocally better" is $10 for personal use or $20 for each public use of the assertion. It is also possible to get a yearly license, but note that this does not include updates. Support is extra. If you wish to use the assertions on a multicore system, there is an additional $5 per core per assertion fee. A student version is available for pedagogical purposes only: "pn src s nqvcll bttr". If you need more than 20 letters, please upgrade to the full version.<x><x>This is the best thing since bread, but don't take my word for it. Here are some trite testimonials putatively from customers:<x><x>"Using I. Ben Fooled's assertion has really revolutionized my work. I love it. I use it every day" ~ Jane, Data Expert<x><x>"I lost 130 lbs on this system", 'wait, this isn't a weightloss testimonial? Sorry!' "My work is easily twice as efficient since I switched to I. Ben Fooled's product." ~ John, Entrepeneur
author: Kevin Wright and Joshua Wiley

quote: As with many tools in this domain, for effective use they require more knowledge than many of their users possess, and can be dangerous because they seem to "work".
author: John C. Nash
context: in the context of stochastic optimization

quote: Unfortunately, this is one of those situations where as far as I can tell all of the real statisticians are out there playing with large data sets where the small-sample corrections are not so important and leaving the rest of us to figure it out for ourselves...
author: Ben Bolker
context: about the 'correct' degrees-of-freedom correction in Wald statistics for GLMMs

quote: David Winsemius: Any of your staff can view the (open) source code just as any other member of the human race.<x>Uwe Ligges:I do not think the GPL excludes other species...
author: David Winsemius and Uwe Ligges
context: following a request for access to the R sources

quote: I think the amount of people on this list who understand your question is roughly zero.
author: Uwe Ligges
context: in response to a non-reproducible problem for which additionally subject and body did not match well

quote: It's not meant for sampling weights. It's meant for precision weights. How best to include sampling weights in mixed models is a research problem at the moment, but you can rely on getting the wrong answer if you just use the weights= argument.
author: Thomas Lumley
context: in reponse to a question about specifying sampling weights in lme4

quote: Perhaps same thing that will happen when those monks finish the Towers of Hanoi?<x>2 * 3^198<x>[1] 5.902533e+94
author: David Winsemius
context: in reponse to a question about expand.grid(x1=1, x2=1:2, x3=1:3, x4=1:3, x5=1:3, ..., x200=1:3)

quote: I'll go back to lurking in the daily R-Helps and not ask any more questions until I've read all the old R-help messages. I'm working on December 1998 right now and reading forward. Perhaps by next year I'll will have read all the old R-help postings and I'll dare ask another question then.
author: Earl F. Glynn

quote: Dirk Eddelbuettel: Devel is in the detail.<x>Douglas Bates: Typo or profound insight?
author: Dirk Eddelbuettel and Douglas Bates

quote: There seem to be three canons: R-Forge, Rforge, and for the Followers of Wickham, github. Four, if you count OmegaHat.
author: David Winsemius
context: in a discussion about the 'canonical' source code management platform for R

quote: The problem here is that the $ notation is a magical shortcut and like any other magic if used incorrectly is likely to do the programmatic equivalent of turning yourself into a toad.
author: Greg Snow
context: in response to a user that wanted to access a column whose name is stored in y via x$y rather than x[[y]]

quote: Etienne B. Racine: I haven't seen any documentation about this behavior.<x>Edzer Pebesma: Isn't the more important question whether you saw documentation that is in conflict with this behaviour?<x>Tom Gottfried: Taking that to the extremes: undocumented software always works perfectly.
author: Etienne B. Racine, Edzer Pebesma, and Tom Gottfried

quote: That's a casual model, not a causal model - you can tell the difference by looking for the word "excel".
author: Hadley Wickham
context: commenting on an Excel chart showing student's SAT score increases with family income, without considering further covariates

quote: Careful now, or I'll get into a rant about how much you pay for ArcGIS and whether you are getting value for money if bugs become 'well-known'! Bugs in R tend to be either 'obscure' or 'fixed' :)
author: Barry Rowlingson
context: in response to a request for rgdal to work around a well-known bug in ArcGIS

quote: Igor Sosa Mayor: The problem is that it gives the result that I want.<x>Sarah Goslee: That's a new sort of problem.
author: Igor Sosa Mayor and Sarah Goslee
